entry.title: Unlocking the NPP: PayID
entry.content:
Welcome to the third installment of the Blog series on the New Payments Platform (“NPP”) in Australia.

The series is planned as:

  1. Unlocking the NPP: SAP Capabilities for Faster, Smarter Payments
  2. Unlocking the NPP: Payments overview
  3. Unlocking the NPP: PayID
  4. Unlocking the NPP: PayTo

 

PayID (OSKO)

PayID can be used as an alternative to specifying a Payee’s Bank Account and BSB details in an online Payment transaction or file. The PayID is chosen by the Payee and can be a mobile number, email address, ABN, or Organisation Identifier. PayID is also referred to as Osko, particularly in the context of Personal Banking.

The initial creation of the PayID is managed directly by the Payee with their Bank, typically through their online banking portal. The Bank will advise their customer (the Payee) which PayID types are available and will validate that the chosen PayID is not already in use, as well as checking it is in the required format. The central registry of PayIDs is part of the NPP infrastructure delivered by Australian Payments Plus (APP), with Banks able to query and update details. Once a PayID is created, the owner can change Banks and just update their existing PayID. 

The main benefits of using PayID in SAP are:

  • You don’t need to request or store Bank Account or BSB details in SAP, which could be regarded as sensitive information similar to Credit Card numbers. Individuals may be reluctant to divulge these as use of PayID / OSKO gains wider usage and security concerns increase.
  • The Payer no longer needs to update Payee Bank details in SAP if the Payee moves Banks or changes Bank Account details.

It is possible for a Payee to have more than one PayID and we’ll describe how this can be handled below.

 

PayID in pain.001 format

APP has produced the document For guidance on using NPP payment initiation messages which contains details on the expected mapping of the PayID (or “Proxy”) fields in the pain.001 file. The document refers to version 11 and describes these fields for PayID for outgoing payments:

  • Type - /CstmrCdtTrfInitn/PmtInf/CdtTrfTxI nf/CdtrAcct/Prxy/Tp/Prtry
  • Value - /CstmrCdtTrfInitn/PmtInf/CdtTrfTxI nf/CdtrAcct/Prxy/Id

You should be aware that these Proxy fields were only added to the ISO20022 pain.001 format in version 09. As described in the previous Blog, SAP standard content refers to version 06 so does not contain these Proxy fields. Similarly where Banks use version 03, these latest standard Proxy fields will not be available and they may direct usage of alternate fields. This can be managed through the standard DMEE configuration activities.

 

PayID in SAP

There are a couple of options for the management of PayID depending on your SAP system:

  • Bank Account Alias
    • Standard function for handling Account Proxy / PayID
    • Available for On Premise / Private Cloud from S/4HANA 2021 FPS01
    • Available in S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • Standard or Custom fields on Business Partner
    • For example if the Supplier uses a Phone number as their PayID, you could use standard fields from the Business Partner Communication data such as Telephone, Telex or Fax. However where these are already populated with different values, it may be necessary to use other fields or create your own.
    • Ensure you are familiar with the mapping process from Business Partner to standard Payment Structures (FPAYP, FPAYHX and FPAYH). Leveraging the standard mapping will make it possible to define the source for PayID within the Payment Format without requiring additional coding.

Source of Information for Field in structures FPAYH-FPAYHX-FPAYP

  • Where coding is required, BAdI FBL_EVENT_06 enables population of ZREF01-ZREF10 fields which can then be mapped to the DMEE fields.

 

Bank Account Alias

We’ll take a look at the configuration and master data settings required to work with the Bank Account Alias using standard SAP functionality.

SSCUI for Public Cloud

IMG for On Premise and Private Cloud

 

Alias Types

  • Alias Type can be created to align to the standard NPP values or any Bank Specific values.
  • Validation determines how the field contents will be checked:
    • Tax number categories references the settings in
      • SSCUI 102415 - Maintain Tax Number Categories
      • SPRO Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide → Cross-Application Components → SAP Business Partner → Business Partner → Basic Settings → Tax Numbers → Define Tax Number Categories
      • Rule AU0 checks “VAT Reg.No. must have the length 11 or 14”
    • Email, Phone number and Organisation use Regular Expressions (code) to validate the length and format of the entries.
    • The NPP mapping guidance document (link above) includes sample RegEx code which can be pasted into each Validation Rule but you can easily create your own using SAP Joule for Consultants or other GenAI tools. Note that the NPP will accept any phone number but you may wish to limit to AU formats for landlines and mobiles (as shown in the above example).

 

Payment System configuration links the Alias Types to the Country.

 

The Bank Account Alias also needs a dedicated “Internal Bank”with Internal bank category set as "Payment System" - a single entry is sufficient for country AU.

Manage Banks - Master Data F6437

 

Business Partner

The Bank Account Alias is maintained under Payment Transactions along with Bank Accounts. The above example shows the Alias is maintained with default ID “0001” which is fine if there is only one entry in the table. We'll see below how to handle BSB / Bank Account and / or additional PaYID for a Business Partner. 

 

The Bank Account Alias details are automatically mapped to the below fields in FFPAYH and from there can be mapped in DMEEX to the required pain.001 nodes.

 

PayID Validation

Whilst PayID has potential benefits, one of the issues to consider is how to ensure the PayID details entered on the Business Partner are correct. The Validation configuration settings will check the format, but will not ensure the actual value is correct and errors are possible. The PayID will be validated for existence by the Bank prior to forwarding the payment file to the NPP, however Customers will be responsible for ensuring the details are correct.

If you process a payment with a PayID through an Online Banking portal, you can view additional details on who the PayID is registered to. This provides additional confidence the payment will reach the desired Payee. This manual check could be used for low volume usage of PayID.

Unfortunately at this stage NPP does not provide the capability to perform automated checks as part of Master Data maintenance or prior to sending the Payment File to SAP or other Digital Service Providers.  The NPP “Confirmation of Payee” service only relates to payments made with BSB and Bank Account.

SAP Customers are recommended to discuss potential solutions with their Banks or to ensure Payees have verified the captured PayID information prior to using in Payment Files.

 

Working with PayID

Business Partner with Bank details and two PayIDs. The field "ID" on the BP Bank Details view is the same as the Partner Bank Type field on an Invoice Document header. The ID values will default to 0001, 0002 etc but can be populated with specific values such as PAY1, PAY2 etc at time of initial creation.

The system will follow the standard sequence for determination of Bank details in the payment run:

  1. Partner Bank Type (ID) in the Invoice document, either from manual entry or substitution. In S/4HANA Public Cloud this could be configuration or BADI.
  2. Partner Bank Type (ID) BTE 1810 (Private Cloud and On Premise only)
  3. Partner Bank Type (ID) with lowest ranking from Blank, then 0001 to ZZZZ. In the above example the Bank Key / Account would continue to be used as the default value of 0001 would be selected first.

Refer KBA 2983466 - Incorrect Partner Bank Type (BVTYP) is selected by Automatic Payment Program for further details.

 

You may also consider whether to create a new Payment Method for PayID payments as the configuration allows setting Bank Account Alias as mandatory on the Business Partner. This also means that only the Payment Alias from the Business Partner is used (not the Bank Account) if the BVTYP is not defined on the document. It also provides an easy way to separate Payment Runs. 

SAP Help – Bank Account Alias

SAP Help – Business Partner – Bank Account Alias

 

PayID for incoming payments

The process of setting up a PayID for incoming payments is managed directly with the Bank. You could use the "Alternative Account number" or create a custom field on the Bank Account master data which can be included on outgoing invoices instead of the BSB and Bank Account details or just manage through Standard Texts. Your customers pay using the PayID but otherwise the Bank Statements and reconciliation process remain unchanged.

entry.title: SAP Cloud ALM for Operations Content Now Available in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Road Map
entry.content:
SAP has added new SAP Cloud ALM for Operations tasks to the SAP Cloud ALM Public Cloud road map. These tasks seamlessly integrate SAP Cloud ALM for Operations functionality into the overall road map, helping customers easily navigate monitoring setup as part of their implementation journey.

The new tasks provide guided setup for the available monitoring capabilities for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. They can be found under the Production Operations Monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM deliverable in the Realize phase and include:

  • Business Process Monitoring – Monitor end-to-end business processes using predefined and custom KPIs to detect issues early.
  • Integration & Exception Monitoring – Gain visibility into integrations with consistent alert handling.
  • User Monitoring – Analyze real user experience and proactively monitor availability using synthetic scenarios.
  • Job & Automation Monitoring – Centrally monitor scheduled jobs and automation across SAP solutions.
  • Health Monitoring – Assess technical and operational system health using metrics from SAP cloud services.

These tasks represent the first set of SAP Cloud ALM for Operations content, with additional tasks planned for Q1 2026. Please check back for future updates on the available monitoring capabilities as new content is released.

entry.title: 浏览迁移对象App——你也能成为数据迁移专家
entry.content:
除了迁移范围，还有迁移顺序

在Cloud ERP里，数据迁移是每个客户、每个项目都会用到的部分。从最早的十几个迁移对象，到现在超过200个迁移对象。我们除了需要定义迁移范围（需要用到哪些迁移对象，因为不可能每个迁移对象都会用到），另外一个非常重要的是需要知道迁移顺序。也就是你所有准备导入的迁移对象里，哪一个先导入，哪一个后导入。在每一次做数据迁移的时候，都需要规划好迁移顺序。虽然在SAP Help Portal的迁移对象页面上，能查到每个迁移对象的前序依赖对象，比如销售订单，你能看到以下迁移对象是它的前序对象，其中客户和产品这两个迁移对象是必须的，其他为可选的。但是文字的方式总不是特别方便。很多客户提出过希望有一个可以图形化查看迁移对象依赖关系的地方……

 

 

千呼万唤始出来

终于，从2508.3版本开始，我们推出了数据迁移下面一个全新的应用“浏览迁移对象”，能够让我们可以图形化的方式来展示迁移对象之间的依赖关系，可以显示迁移对象的必须或可选的前序对象。

这个应用的权限信息如下：

业务目录：SAP_CA_BC_MIG_PC

默认的业务角色：SAP_BR_CONFIG_EXPERT_DATA_MIG

 

 

深入浅出“浏览迁移对象”

当你打开应用“浏览迁移对象”，你会看到下面这样一个界面。可以有两种方式来显示迁移对象的依赖关系：

  1. 在所有当前可用的迁移对象里，选择某个迁移对象，来显示它的前序对象。
  2. 因为我们的功能是按照范围项目（Scope item）来划分的，有时候我们想知道某个范围项目牵涉到哪些迁移对象。所以你也可以选择某个范围项目，来显示跟这个范围项目相关的迁移对象。

 

 

根据迁移对象查看

比如，选择迁移对象“客户 - 按新组织级别扩展现有记录”（CUST_EXT_3），你会看到以下这个界面：

 

你选择的迁移对象会显示在最左边，它的前序依赖对象在它的右边。

你能看到有两种不同的线，橙色的实线代表这个前序对象是必须的，也就是如果你要导入“客户 - 按新组织级别扩展现有记录”，你必须先导入“客户”这个迁移对象。灰色的虚线代表是可选的前序对象。在这个例子里，“FI-CA 合同合作伙伴”、“银行”和“供应商”是3个可选的前序迁移对象。

 

在上方，你能看到一条菜单栏如下：

 

点击Transpose按钮，你可以把图形在横向展示和竖向展示之间切换。不同的情况可能不同的展示方式更为方便，或者方便你截图：

 

 

菜单上也可以点击显示图例：

 

以及缩放和全屏显示的按钮。

 

当然，这个应用绝不是这些功能这么简单！

如果你点击某个节点，在这个节点的右方，会出现几个节点按钮：

 

你可以选择折叠或展开与该节点相关的其他节点，也可以快速跳转到这个迁移对象的详细文档页面。你也可以点击某个节点，来展示与它相关的前序迁移对象。

 

根据范围项目来查看

你也可以根据范围项目来查看与它相关的迁移对象。例如，你选择BLF（批次管理），你会得到以下这个界面：

 

这就展示了如果需要使用BLF批次管理，那么这些迁移对象需要考虑做导入。这个功能也方便了我们的功能顾问来规划迁移范围，不会遗漏应该需要导入的数据。

同样的，我也可以点击上面的任何节点，来展示它是否还有前序对象。比如我选择“类”这个对象，显示依赖关系，我会得到以下的界面：

 

你可以看到，类这个迁移对象，它有两个可选的前序对象。

 

未来功能的展望

对于这个新应用，还是会有一些新的功能点在未来会被支持。比如，不是显示所有的迁移对象，而是显示在这个系统中被激活的迁移对象可能会更合适。

另外，显示迁移对象的类型，主数据或者交易数据，这也会是一个经常会用到的过滤点。也有计划会展示迁移对象是否支持关键用户扩展。

 

如果你想要了解更详细的关于浏览迁移对象（Explore Migration Objects）的介绍，你也可以看一下我们的数据迁移专家Frank Finkbohner的博文：The New Explore Migration Objects App, The Game Ch... - SAP Community

 

最后，希望你会喜欢这个数据迁移的新应用。如果你有任何问题，欢迎留言！

entry.title: Guide to the Return STO Process in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Hello, SAP Community!

Reverse logistics is an integral part of any robust supply chain. Whether it's due to quality issues, excess stock, or a simple change in plans, the need to return materials from one plant to another is a common business requirement. In the world of SAP, this is managed through the Return Stock Transport Order (Return STO) process.

While the concept isn't new, its execution in SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public edition) with its Fiori-first methodology that makes the difference. This guide will walk you through the functional steps, highlight the key Fiori apps involved, and clarify the differences between the primary return scenarios.

Let's dive in!

What is a Return STO?

A standard Stock Transport Order (STO) is used to move articles / materials from a Supplying plant (A) to a Receiving plant (B). A Return STO simply reverses this flow. The plant that originally received the goods (i.e) Plant (B) now acts as the "Supplying" plant, sending the stock back to the original source Plant (A).

The key trigger for this process is a specific "Returns Item" indicator in the Purchase Order, which tells the system to handle the logistics in reverse.

The Core Scenarios for Return STOs

In S/4HANA Cloud Public release, the Return STO process can be broadly categorized into two main scenarios, each suiting different business needs.

Scenario 1: Simple Return (Without a Delivery Document)

This is the most straightforward method. It's ideal for returns over short distances or within the same campus, where formal shipping documentation isn't necessary. The entire process is managed within Inventory Management (MM-IM).


Process Flow:

  1. Create a Return Purchase Order (Manage Purchase Orders)
  2. Post a Goods Issue directly against the Purchase Order.
  3. Post a Goods Receipt at the receiving plant.

Key Characteristics & Apps:

  • No Shipping (LE-SHP) Integration: You do not create an outbound delivery.
  • Goods Movement: The process is a direct plant-to-plant transfer posting.
  • Key Fiori App: Post Goods Movement (MIGO)
    • You use this app to post the "Goods Issue" from the sending plant, referencing the Return PO. The system automatically uses Movement Type 161. This movement type simultaneously reduces stock at the sending plant and increases the "Stock in Transit" for the receiving plant.
    • The receiving plant then uses the same app to post the Goods Receipt, completing the process.

Scenario 2: Return with an Outbound Delivery

This process is typically covered under the Best Practices scope item 1P9 (Stock Transfer with Delivery),  is the more common and structured process, especially when goods are moving between geographically separate locations. It integrates with the Logistics Execution (LE) part of the system, allowing for proper shipping, picking, and transportation planning.

Process Flow:

  1. Create a Return Purchase Order (with the returns flag).
  2. Create an Outbound Delivery based on the PO.
  3. Pick the items for the delivery (if warehouse-managed).
  4. Post the Goods Issue from the delivery.
  5. Post the Goods Receipt at the receiving plant, referencing the delivery.

Key Characteristics & Apps:

  • Shipping (LE-SHP) Integration: The creation of an Outbound Delivery is a mandatory step.
  • Structured Process: Allows for better tracking, packing, and handling of the shipment.
  • Key Fiori Apps:
    • Create Purchase Order - Advanced (App id : F0842A): The starting point.
    • My Outbound Deliveries (or Create Outbound Deliveries - From Stock Transport Orders): Used to create the delivery document from the Return PO.
    • Post Goods Issue: You post the GI directly from the outbound delivery document, which uses Movement Type 671 (for a two-step transfer). This moves the stock into "Stock in Transit".
    • Post Goods Movement (MIGO): The receiving plant references the outbound delivery or PO to post the goods receipt, using Movement Type 161 to move stock from "Stock in Transit" to plant storage.

A Step-by-Step Walkthrough (Scenario 2: Return with Delivery)

Let's walk through the most common scenario to see the apps in action.

Step 1: Create the Return Purchase Order

  • App: Create Purchase Order - Advanced
  • Action:
    • Select the appropriate Purchase Order type for STOs.
    • Enter the receiving plant in the header (this is the plant the goods are going back to).
    • In the item details, enter the supplying plant (the plant sending the goods back).
    • Crucially, check the "Returns Item" checkbox on the item detail screen. This is what makes it a Return STO.
    • Save the PO.

Step 2: Create the Outbound Delivery

  • App: My Outbound Deliveries or Create Outbound Deliveries - From Stock Transport Orders
  • Action:
    • The system will show your Return PO as a shipping due list item.
    • Select the item and create the outbound delivery. The system automatically determines the correct delivery type based on your configuration.

Step 3: Post Goods Issue (PGI)

  • App: From within the Outbound Delivery document you just created.
  • Action:
    • If picking is required, you'll perform that step first.
    • Click "Post Goods Issue".
    • The system will post the goods movement in the background (Movement Type 671). You can check the stock status using the Stock - Single Material app, where you will see the quantity now in "Stock in Transit".

Step 4: Post Goods Receipt (GR)

  • App: Post Goods Movement
  • Action:
    • The receiving plant's clerk opens the app.
    • Select "Goods Receipt" and "Purchase Order" (or "Outbound Delivery").
    • Enter the Return PO number or the delivery number.
    • The system will pull in the data, including the correct Movement Type (161).
    • Post the document. The stock is now moved from "Stock in Transit" into the receiving plant's specified storage location (e.g., Unrestricted or Blocked stock). 

 Key Differences at a Glance
 

Feature

Scenario 1: Return without Delivery

Scenario 2: Return with Delivery

Core Process

Purely Inventory Management (IM)

Integrated with Logistics Execution (LE-SHP)

Key Document

Purchase Order

Purchase Order + Outbound Delivery

Goods Issue App

Post Goods Movement

My Outbound Deliveries (or related apps)

Goods Issue Mov. Type

161 (One-Step Transfer Posting)

671 (Two-Step Transfer to Stock in Transit)

Goods Receipt Mov. Type

(N/A - Part of the 161 movement)

161 (Receipt from Stock in Transit)

Use Case

Internal, short-distance transfers

Formal, long-distance, planned shipments

Final Thoughts

The Return STO process in SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public edition) is flexible, robust, and fully integrated into the Fiori landscape. The key is to understand your business requirement first: do you need the formality of a shipment, or is a simple inventory transfer sufficient? Once you've answered that, you can follow the corresponding app-driven path.

By leveraging the "Returns Item" indicator and the correct sequence of Fiori apps, you can manage your reverse logistics efficiently and with full visibility.

What are your experiences with Return STOs in the Public Cloud? Have you encountered any unique scenarios or have tips to share? Please leave your thoughts in the comments below!

entry.title: Working with CDS I_APIsWithCloudDevSuccessor For Cloud Development (SAP S4HANA Public Cloud)
entry.content:
Note : This Blog contains parts of SAP standard documentation and my point of observation.

I_APISWITHCLOUDDEVSUCCESSOR :  APIs with Cloud Development Successors.

Apart from the Business accelerator hub   or Cloudification Repository Viewer  you would have heard from your fellow developers that there is a CDS view available in the SAP Public cloud system to check for the released and available cloud development ready objects . Here comes the I_APIsWithCloudDevSuccessor CDS view , using this CDS view you can get all the cloud ready objects (Business objects , Latest API ) for the existing objects (Tables , CDS)  . 

Existing SAP Standard code:

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_ALLOWED
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@EndUserText.label: 'APIs with Cloud Development Successors'
define view entity I_APIsWithCloudDevSuccessor
  // Option 1: Predecessor has one or more successors for cloud development
  as select from ars_w_api_state               as predecessor
    inner join   ARS_API_SUCCESSORS_FOR_C1_SCP as successor           on  predecessor.object_type     = successor.tadir_object
                                                                      and predecessor.object_name     = successor.tadir_obj_name
                                                                      and predecessor.sub_object_type = successor.object_type
                                                                      and predecessor.sub_object_name = successor.object_key
    inner join   ARS_RUNTIME_API_STATE         as cloud_dev_successor on  cloud_dev_successor.object_type               = successor.successor_tadir_object
                                                                      and cloud_dev_successor.object_name               = successor.successor_tadir_obj_name
                                                                      and cloud_dev_successor.sub_object_type           = successor.successor_object_type
                                                                      and cloud_dev_successor.sub_object_name           = successor.successor_object_key
                                                                      and cloud_dev_successor.compatibility_contract    = 'C1' // System-internal use
                                                                      and cloud_dev_successor.use_in_sap_cloud_platform = 'X'  // Use in cloud development
                                                                      and cloud_dev_successor.release_state             = 'RELEASED'
  association [0..1] to v_ars_release_state as _text on _text.state = predecessor.release_state
{
  key predecessor.sub_object_type                         as PredecessorObjectType,
  key predecessor.sub_object_name                         as PredecessorObjectName,
  key predecessor.object_type                             as PredecessorObjectDirectoryType,
  key predecessor.object_name                             as PredecessorObjectDirectoryName,
  key successor.successor_object_type                     as SuccessorObjectType,
  key successor.successor_object_key                      as SuccessorObjectName,
  key successor.successor_tadir_object                    as SuccessorObjectDirectoryType,
  key successor.successor_tadir_obj_name                  as SuccessorObjectDirectoryName,
      predecessor.successor_concept_name                  as SuccessorConceptName,
      cast('O' as ars_successor_category preserving type) as SuccessorCategory, // Object
      predecessor.release_state                           as PredecessorReleaseState,
      _text.description                                   as PredecessorReleaseStateDescr
}
where
       predecessor.compatibility_contract    = 'C1' // System-internal use
  and  predecessor.use_in_sap_cloud_platform = 'X' // Use in cloud development
  and(
       predecessor.successor_classification  = '1' // One object
    or predecessor.successor_classification  = 'N' // Multiple objects
  )

// Option 2: Predecessor was replaced by a concept
union select from ars_w_api_state as predecessor
association [0..1] to v_ars_release_state as _text on _text.state = predecessor.release_state
{
  key predecessor.sub_object_type                         as PredecessorObjectType,
  key predecessor.sub_object_name                         as PredecessorObjectName,
  key predecessor.object_type                             as PredecessorObjectDirectoryType,
  key predecessor.object_name                             as PredecessorObjectDirectoryName,
  key ''                                                  as SuccessorObjectType,
  key ''                                                  as SuccessorObjectName,
  key ''                                                  as SuccessorObjectDirectoryType,
  key ''                                                  as SuccessorObjectDirectoryName,
      predecessor.successor_concept_name                  as SuccessorConceptName,
      cast('C' as ars_successor_category preserving type) as SuccessorCategory, // Concept
      predecessor.release_state                           as PredecessorReleaseState,
      _text.description                                   as PredecessorReleaseStateDescr
}
where
      predecessor.compatibility_contract    = 'C1' // System-internal use
  and predecessor.use_in_sap_cloud_platform = 'X' // Use in cloud development
  and predecessor.successor_classification  = 'X' // Concept

  The view I_APIsWithCloudDevSuccessor returns development objects which themselves either cannot be used or should no longer be used in cloud development, together with one or more successors that can be used instead.

A successor can be one of the following:

  1. a development object that was released as API for system-internal use (contract C1) and visibility Use in Cloud Development, as specified in the ABAP Development Tools, using the API State tab of the Properties view
  2. a concept which replaces the development object.

The predecessor and successor objects returned by this view are identified by their object type and name.
In most cases, object type and name are identical with the respective object directory type and name.
Exceptions from this rule are the following:

Description Object Type Object Name Object Directory Type Object Directory Name

CDS EntityCDS_STOB<CDS Entity Name>DDLS<Data Definition Name>
BAdI DefinitionBADI_DEF<BAdI Definition Name>ENHS<Enhancement Spot Name>
Function ModuleFUNC<Function Module Name>FUGR<Function Group Name>

SAP Released ABAP Object Types :

You might not find every type , but more and more objects are getting added after every release.

 

APIS

API Release State of Objects

APLO

Application Log Object

AUTH

Authorization Check Fields

BDEF

Behavior Definition

BGQC

Background Processing Context

CDBO

Customer Data Browser Object

CFDF

Custom Field

CHDO

Change Document

CHKC

ATC Check Category

CHKO

Field Explanations : 

PredecessorObjectType

Object type of the predecessor object which cannot be used or should no longer be used

PredecessorObjectName

Name of the predecessor object which cannot be used or should no longer be used

PredecessorObjectDirectoryType

Object type of the predecessor object in the object directory (TABL:TADIR.OBJECT)

PredecessorObjectDirectoryName

Name of the predecessor object in the object directory (TABL:TADIR.OBJ_NAME)

SuccessorObjectType

Object type of the successor object

SuccessorObjectName

Name of the successor object

SuccessorObjectDirectoryType

Object type of the successor object in the object directory (TABL:TADIR.OBJECT)

SuccessorObjectDirectoryName

Name of the successor object in the object directory (TABL:TADIR.OBJ_NAME)

SuccessorConceptName

Name of the concept which replaces the predecessor object

SuccessorCategory

Indicates whether the successor is a released development object or a concept

Allowed values are:

  • 'O': released development object
  • 'C': concept

PredecessorReleaseState

Release state of the predecessor object

Allowed values are:

  • 'NOT_TO_BE_RELEASED': The object will not be released and thus cannot be used.
  • 'DEPRECATED': The object was formerly released but is now deprecated and thus should no longer be used.

PredecessorReleaseStateDescr

Language-dependent description of the PredecessorReleaseState

 

What I have done to this CDS view to make it more readable and Provide sense to my Peers :

I have written the following code and exposed the CDS in a service and deployed the same as an APP for my junior collogues to refer and learn easily and this is always in the Dev environment as a Tile.

Note : I know that cloudification repository does exist but sometimes , its easier to guide peers with internal tools . I always love creating objects for internal use 🙂  .

Code : 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'APIs With Cloud Development Successors'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define view entity ZI_APIsWithCloudDevSuccessor
  as select from I_APIsWithCloudDevSuccessor
{
      @EndUserText.label: 'Predecessor Object Name'
      .identification: [ {  position: 1  } ]
      .lineItem: [ {  position: 1  } ]
  key PredecessorObjectName,

      .hidden: true
  key PredecessorObjectType,

      @EndUserText.label: 'Predecessor Object Directory Type'
      .hidden: true
  key PredecessorObjectDirectoryType,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Predecessor Object Directory Name'
      .hidden: true
  key PredecessorObjectDirectoryName,
      .hidden: true
  key SuccessorObjectType,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Successor Object Name'
      .identification: [ {  position: 3  } ]
      .lineItem: [ {  position: 3  } ]
  key SuccessorObjectName,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Successor Object Directory Type'
      .hidden: true
  key SuccessorObjectDirectoryType,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Successor Object Directory Name'
      .hidden: true
  key SuccessorObjectDirectoryName,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Successor Concept Name'
      .identification: [ {  position: 5  } ]
      .lineItem: [ {  position: 5  } ]
      SuccessorConceptName,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Successor Category'
      .identification: [ {  position: 6  } ]
      .lineItem: [ {  position: 6 } ]
      case SuccessorCategory
      when 'O' then  'Object'
      when 'C' then 'Concept'
      end as SuccessorCategory,

      @EndUserText.label: 'Predecessor Release State'
      .identification: [ {  position: 7  } ]
      .lineItem: [ {  position: 7 , criticality: 'PredecessorReleaseState' ,criticalityRepresentation: #WITH_ICON } ]
      PredecessorReleaseStateDescr,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Predecessor Release State'
      .hidden: true
      case when PredecessorReleaseState = 'DEPRECATED' then 1
      when PredecessorReleaseState = 'NOT_TO_BE_RELEASED' then 2
      end as PredecessorReleaseState,

      @EndUserText.label: 'Predecessor Object Type'
      .identification: [ {  position: 2  } ]
      .lineItem: [ {  position: 2  } ]
      case
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'FUNC' then 'Function Module'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'TABL' then 'Table Definition'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'BADI_DEF' then 'BADI Definition'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'CLAS' then 'Class'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'INTF' then 'Interface'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'SUSO' then 'Authorization Object'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'DOMA' then 'Domain'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'DTEL' then 'Data Element'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'CHKV' then 'ATC Check Variant'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'CDS_STOB' then 'CDS-Core Data Services Runtime Object'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'SIA2' then 'IAM: Restriction Type'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'TTYP' then 'Table Type'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'FDT0' then 'FDT/BRFplus: System Application'
      end as PredecessorObjectTypeDesc,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Successor Object Type'
      .identification: [ {  position: 4  } ]
      .lineItem: [ {  position: 4  } ]
      case
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'FUNC' then 'Function Module'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'TABL' then 'Table Definition'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'BADI_DEF' then 'BADI Definition'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'CLAS' then 'Class'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'INTF' then 'Interface'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'SUSO' then 'Authorization Object'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'DOMA' then 'Domain'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'DTEL' then 'Data Element'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'CHKV' then 'ATC Check Variant'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'CDS_STOB' then 'CDS-Core Data Services Runtime Object'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'SIA2' then 'IAM: Restriction Type'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'TTYP' then 'Table Type'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'FDT0' then 'FDT/BRFplus: System Application'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'BDEF' then 'Behavior Definition'
      end as SuccessorObjectTypeDesc


      //      case
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'CHKV' then 'ATC Check Variant'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'CLAS' then 'Class'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'DDLS' then 'CDS-Data Definition Language Source'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'DOMA' then 'Domain'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'DTEL' then 'Data Element'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'ENHS' then 'BADI Enhancement'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'FDT0' then 'FDT/BRFplus: System Application'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'FUGR' then 'Function Group'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'INTF' then 'Interface'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'SIA2' then 'IAM: Restriction Type'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'SUSO' then 'Authorization Object'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'TABL' then 'Table Definition'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'TTYP' then 'Table Type'
      //        end                                                                                                     as PredeObjectDirectoryTypeDesc,

      //      concat_with_space( $projection.PredecessorObjectTypeDesc , $projection.PredeObjectDirectoryTypeDesc , 1 ) as PredecessorObjectType2
}

entry.title: Canada T4A-NR 2025 Regulatory Changes: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance(DRC)
entry.content:
Towards the end of 2025, the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) rolled out updates to the T4A-NR slip, summary forms, and the T619 XML schema. These changes, which will affect filings due on or before the last day of February 2026, have been seamlessly integrated into SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) solutions, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition /On-Premise. Here’s a detailed look at what these updates entail and how SAP is ensuring compliance.

Key Regulatory Changes

  1. Updated CRA Forms: The CRA has released new 2025 versions of the T4A-NR slip and the T4A-NR Summary (T4A-NR-SUM) for the 2025 tax year. While the content changes are minimal, using the correct form version is essential to avoid filing issues.
  2. T619 XML Schema Updates:
    • Mandatory Language Code: To ensure consistent language identification for CRA communications, the T619 electronic transmittal now requires a language code to specify English or French, denoted by “E” or “F” for every submission. Previously optional, this field is now mandatory for 2025 filings.
    • No Empty Fields in XML: A new validation rule mandates that any optional XML element with no data must be omitted entirely. This means if a data field doesn’t apply or is blank, the system should not generate that XML tag at all, as including empty tags can lead to file rejection by the CRA. 

SAP's Support of Regulatory Changes

As part ofSAP’s end-to-end compliance vision, the SAP Globalization Product Management team has proactively delivered the necessary updates to accommodate these CRA changes, to ensure that customers can generate compliant T4A-NR slips, summaries, and XML files across SAP Cloud ERP solutions:

  • SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: The T4A-NR form and summary Adobe print forms have been updated in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to match the CRA’s 2025 PDF layout. Electronic filing content for T4A-NR has been enhanced to output XML according to the new schema, delivered via the regular quarterly release.
  •  SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition/On-Premise: SAP Note 3691523 – “Canada T4A-NR Withholding Tax Reporting: Legal Changes 2025” was released, along with a support package containing the updated forms and electronic report definitions. Applying this note or support pack will ensure the system produces the correct 2025 forms and XML.

Next Steps 

  • Review and Implement SAP Update: Ensure your SAP S/4HANA system has the 2025 year-end legal change for T4A-NR applied. For SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, apply SAP Note 3691523. For SAP S/4HANA Cloud, confirm you’re on the latest release that includes the T4A-NR changes. Implement these updates before year-end processing.
  • Test Your Reporting: Generate a sample T4A-NR slip, summary, and XML file in a test environment. Verify that the slip and summary display “2025” and the latest form text. Ensure the language element is present and correctly set, and confirm that there are no empty tags in the file.
  • Consult CRA Resources: Refer to the CRA’s official XML specifications page for the updated schema download and guidance for 2025/2026 filings. The CRA’s T4A-NR guide (RC4445) for 2025, updated December 2025, is also a helpful reference. Links to the schema files and CRA documentation are available on the CRA website.

Call to Action

SAP customers and partners can avoid last-minute scrambles and ensure a smooth tax filing season by taking the following actions:

  • Review our published "What's New" SAP Help Portal documentation, apply, and test the delivered SAP changes promptly.
  • Engage your IT or SAP support team to confirm that your system is outputting the new form and schema correctly. Leverage the Regulatory Change Manager for agility in adapting to new legal requirements.
  • Visit the CRA’s XML specification page for the official schema and test your files against it. With proper preparation, you’ll be ready to file your 2025 T4A‑NR returns without issues.
  • Connect with us via the SAP support channels or Canada Localization Workzone if questions arise during this update process.

entry.title: Legal Change - IDIS scenario support through Extensibility in DRC Türkiye
entry.content:
This blog post provides a step-by-step guide on how to implement the new legal requirement released by GIB (GELİR İDARESİ BAŞKANLIĞI) for eInvoice and eDespatch under the Construction Rebar Tracking System (IDIS) using Developer Extensibility for Document and Reporting Compliance Türkiye in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Background:
We have already published a blog titled Developer Extensibility for Document and Reporting Compliance Türkiye in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud which explains how SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud customers can leverage developer extensibility to modify the content of XML files generated during electronic invoice submissions, in accordance with specific business and legal requirements.

Note for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and ECC environments:
In SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and SAP ECC environments, the same extensibility approach is available. However, in these systems, the BAdI implementation must be carried out for EDOC_ADAPTOR instead of EDOC_ADAPTOR_CLOUD.

What’s New?
GIB has published a legal requirement for invoices issued under the Construction Rebar Tracking System, which impacts certain companies starting from 21st November 2025. In this blog, we aim to address this requirement by building on the learnings from the previous blog highlighted in the background.

What are the technical specifications of the requirement?
Currently, the system does not automatically determine whether a billing or finance document is related to the Construction Rebar Tracking  System. Customers must explicitly indicate that the invoice belongs to a Construction Rebar Tracking System and provide the required values.
As part of the legal requirements published by the authorities, the following new Profile IDs must be used in the UBL (Universal Business Language, an ISO standard XML) representation:

  1. IDIS - for eInvoice Scenarios
  2. IDISIRSALIYE – for eDespatch scenarios

eInvoice

  • ProfileID for IDIS Scenario
    For IDIS-relevant invoices, the ProfileID in the UBL-TR XML will be set to IDIS.
    • Cardinality: 1 (Mandatory)
    • This value determines that the invoice belongs to the IDIS scenario
    • The solution will automatically populate this value for applicable

  • Shipment Number (Sevkiyat Numarası) at Header Level:
    • Mapped to: Invoice/AccountingSupplierParty/Party/PartyIdentification
      SE-<number> with schemeID as SEVKIYATINO – This would carry the shipment number prefixed with SE. The total number of characters is 10.
      Example: SE-1345840
    • IssueDate should be filled with the investment certificate date in DD/MM/YYYY format

  • Tag Number (Etiket Numarası) at Item Level:
    • Invoice/InvoiceLine/Item/AdditionalItemIdentification/ID should be filled with tag number generated within the scope of IDIS (Rebar Monitoring System). This number is a 9-character alphanumeric value, where the first 2 characters are letters followed by 7 numeric digits. 
      SchemeID should be ETIKETNO.
      Example: CV0152457

eDespatch

  • ProfileID for IDISIRSALIYE Scenario
    For IDISIRSALIYE-relevant invoices, the ProfileID in the UBL-TR XML will be set to IDISIRSALIYE.
    • Cardinality: 1 (Mandatory)
    • This value determines that the invoice belongs to the IDISIRSALIYE scenario
    • The solution will automatically populate this value for applicable

  • Shipment Number (Sevkiyat Numarası) at Header Level:
    • Mapped to: /DespatchAdvice/DespatchSupplierParty/Party/PartyIdentification
      SE-<number> with schemeID as SEVKIYATINO – This would carry the shipment number prefixed with SE. The total number of characters is 10.
      Example: SE-1345840
    • IssueDate should be filled with the investment certificate date in DD/MM/YYYY format

  • Tag Number (Etiket Numarası) at Item Level:
    • /DespatchAdvice/DespatchLine/Item/AdditionalItemIdentification/ID should be filled with tag number generated within the scope of IDIS (Rebar Monitoring System). This number is a 9-character alphanumeric value, where the first 2 characters are letters followed by 7 numeric digits. 
      SchemeID should be ETIKETNO.
      Example: CV0152457

Result:
When you display the XML file of the electronic document in the eDocument Cockpit (EDOC_COCKPIT) corresponding to the above invoicing scenario, you will see that the mentioned tags are populated accordingly. Please note that any error handling and troubleshooting will depend on the actual submission of this document to the authorized service provider.

Conclusion:
With recent enhancements to the Türkiye Document and Reporting Compliance solution, SAP has made it significantly easier to tailor electronic document outputs.
This improvement gives you more flexibility and helps ensure compliance with Türkiye’s legal requirements.

entry.title: SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council (ESAC) – Q1 Update
entry.content:
Would you like more hands-on support for your ongoing projects and earlier access to new support offerings?

SAP Enterprise Support delivers foundational support and is included with every SAP cloud subscription at no additional cost. Through SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council (ESAC), we collaborate directly with customers like you to continuously enhance essential services and support content across all cloud solutions.

ESAC is a collaborative innovation program that brings together SAP experts and a select group of customers to explore new ideas, share feedback, and help shape the future of SAP Enterprise Support.

By participating in ESAC, you can:

  • Engage with a trusted network of industry peers and receive practical, expert advice
  • Gain early access to new services and tools, with opportunities to pilot and influence them

ESAC brings customers and SAP experts together to turn your feedback into real support improvements.

New Workstreams in Q1

Continuous Quality Checks (CQC*):

  • CQC Deployment Readiness for SAP Digital Manufacturing
  • CQC Deployment Readiness for SAP Signavio Process Manager and Collaboration Hub
  • CQC Deployment Readiness for the Integrated Toolchain
  • CQC Security Optimization for SAP Integrated Business Planning (Blog)
  • CQC Security Optimization for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Blog)
  • CQC Security Optimization for SAP SuccessFactors (Blog)

Expert-Guided Implementations (EGI*):

  • EGI Territory Management for Sales Employees and Administrators, SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 (Blog)

Other Services: Revamped Customer Center of Expertise (COE) Team Accreditation Assessment

The following workstreams remain open to customers:

  • Release Navigator: Upgrade Resources for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  • CQC Technical Preparation for SAP Signavio Process Insights and Intelligence 

View the workstream overviews

For more information, visit us on SAP Support Portal.

To express interest or join the program: contact us via esac@sap.com.

Your SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council team

*Continuous Quality Check (CQC): Work with our experts to analyse your system and/or situation based on real-life system or solution data. You will receive a service report with an executive summary, findings, and a detailed action plan to help improve outcomes or mitigate risks.

*Expert-Guided Implementation (EGI): A multi-day, remote, workshop-style session where participants learn to complete a defined activity with the support of experienced SAP service engineers.

entry.title: Key User Custom Fields: Finding the business context for a given database table
entry.content:
Key User Custom Fields: Finding the business context for a given database table  

Have you ever been in a situation where you wanted to add a key user custom field to a given database table (e.g. ACDOCA or VBAK), but you did not know which business context to choose? 

Or are you right in the middle of an ECC to SAP S/4HANA migration project, and you have legacy custom fields in your ECC system? You want to recreate custom fields in SAP S/4HANA, and you don’t know which business context to choose?  

If your answer is yes, then this blog post is just for you. In this blog, you’ll find out how to determine the right business context based on a given database table name (or CI-include name or extension include name). 
The ways to determine the right business context differ between SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (and on premise).

How do business contexts relate to database tables?  

When you create a custom field using the Custom Fields app, you must first choose a business context. A business context describes the business entity which you want to extend. Technically, each business context has an include structure assigned, which is directly or transitively included in one or more database tables. This include structure is also called persistence include or extension include structure. 
If you add a custom field to a business context, this field is added to the respective persistence include structure using an append structure. With that, all database tables and structures which include this persistence include structure automatically also get this field. 

You can get more detailed information in the following SAP Help documentation: Handling_of_Legacy_Fields.pdf 
 
Now that you have an idea of how business contexts relate to database tables, let’s understand  

  1. how to figure out the respective business context for a given database table and 
  1. how to figure out the database table(s) which get extended when you add a field to a business context 

Figuring out the business context based on a given object in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and on premise 

Report CFD_GET_BUS_CTXTS_BY_DB_TABLE allows you to enter a database table name, a CI-include name, or an extension include name. When running the report, all business contexts that expose fields in the respective database table/CI-include/extension include are listed. 
This report is part of SAP note 3699976 - Custom Fields: find business contexts for db table

Figuring out database table(s) that are extended by a business context in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and on premise 

Report CFD_GET_DB_TABLES_BY_BUS_CTXT allows you to enter a business context name. As a result, a list of all database tables that contain the fields of the given business context is displayed. This report is also part of SAP note 3699976 - Custom Fields: find business contexts for db table 

Figuring out the business context based on a given database table in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you can use the Extensibility Assistant (see this blog for details) that helps you to create and maintain custom fields. In one of the next releases (probably already with the 2608 release) the Extensibility Assistant will also be able to tell you which business context to choose to extend a given database table. If you enter a prompt like “Which business context should I use in order to extend table VBAK?”, the extensibility assistant will be able to help you. 

Please note that this blog has been elaborated by a team of experts. I want to thank Yasmina van Rooij (YasminavanRooij),  and Karsten Schaser (Karsten_Schaser) for their extremely helpful contributions. 

Feedback, Comments, or Questions: 

You’re cordially invited to provide feedback, comments, or questions in the comments section below. Please follow our profiles to get updates when we publish more posts on these topics. 
Feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/). 

Other related blog posts: 

  1. Extensibility Assistant for Key Users: The extensibility expert right next to you  
  1. Key User Custom Fields in S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and On-Premise: Dos and Don’ts  
  1. Convert Manually Created Append Fields to Real Key User Custom Fields

entry.title: How to Configure South Korea Tax Box Structure VAT01 for Form and File Changes
entry.content:
一. Background and Symptom

The form and files have changed in the General Taxpayer VAT Declaration report for South Korea.

The General Taxpayer VAT Declaration report enables you to generate your General Taxpayer VAT Declaration and fulfill the statutory reporting requirements in South Korea. You generate this report in the Run Statutory Reports app.

The following tax box definitions need to be updated:

  1. Adjust the following tax box numbers:

Old Tax Box Number

New Tax Box Number

Description

10-1

11

Import Payment Incentives of Export Company

20-1

22

VAT-Exempt Amount for Small Personal Business

        2. Create a new tax box as follows:

Tax Box Number

Description

25

Interim Assessment Tax Amount

二. Prerequisites

This SAP KBA is relevant only for South Korea. Ensure that you have the necessary authorizations as delivered with the Configuration Expert - Business Process Configuration (SAP_BR_BPC_EXPERT) business role template.

三. Solution

You can change the tax box structure definition via the configuration activity Define Enhanced Tax Box Structure (ID 103011). Follow the steps below to modify, delete, and add the required tax groups and tax boxes.

Steps:

  1. Open the configuration activity Define Enhanced Tax Box Structure (ID 103011).
  • In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the activity.
    If you are using the Manage Your Solution app, select the activity under Finance > Statutory Reporting > Tax.
    If you are using the CBC system, select the activity under Accounting > Tax Management > Tax Declaration > Tax Declaration.

        2. Open the coSelect the target country/region.

  • Select “South Korea” as the target country/region.

        3. Copy the tax box structure to a new version.
             To make changes, you must copy the tax box structure as a new version. This ensures that all changes are done in the new                        version of the tax box structure.

  • Select the current tax box structure, and click Copy As.

  • Specify a new Valid From date. Note that the Valid From date should not be the same as other Valid From dates under the same tax box structure type (TaxBoxStTy).

  • Click Copy or press Enter. And press Enter again if a warning message appears.

  • Click Copy All to copy the existing record to this new tax box structure version.

  • Click Save after you copied it. A new record will be displayed under VAT01.

        4. Delete tax boxes.

  • In the new version of the tax box structure, select the Define Tax Boxes (External) tab.
  • Select the following tax boxes:

Tax Box Number

Description

Comments

19

(19)Credit Card Slips, Issuance Deduction and Others

Replaced by 20

23

(23)Tax Amount of Business Transferee Proxy Pre-Payment

Replaced by 26

31

(31)Exception (Sales of Fixed Asset and Supply to a Direct Store)

Replaced by 34

41

(41)General Purchase with Credit Card Slip and Cash Receipt

Replaced by 44

42

(42)Fixed Asset Purchase with Credit Card Slip and Cash Receipt

Replaced by 45

43

(43)Deemed Purchase Tax

Replaced by 46

52

(52)Purchase Tax Amount Returned to Tax Office

Replaced by 55

entry.title: Accelerate your cloud adoption journey with Cloud Integration Automation service
entry.content:
As many customers adopt SAP Business Suite—a comprehensive set of integrated solutions combining Cloud ERP with Line of Business (LOB) applications, integration becomes a critical architectural pillar for delivering seamless, end-to-end business processes and unlocking the full potential of the SAP Business Suite.  
 
Typically, integration requires an extensive review of documentation, identification of all relevant components and entities, system landscape, creation of a detailed integration plan and the engagement of the appropriate subject matter experts with multiple reiterations. Altogether, these steps make integration a complex and time-consuming process. 

To address this, the Cloud Integration Automation service creates one consolidated guided workflow that orchestrates every step across the entire integration process. 

While the Cloud Integration Automation Service supports both public and private cloud scenarios, this blog focuses on providing an in-depth look at the public cloud scenarios available and how they can be utilized to accelerate your cloud adoption journey. 

Cloud Integration Automation service: Introduction 

Cloud Integration Automation service is an SAP BTP based integration application that comes with no additional cost that generates guided workflow to integrate SAP cloud solutions to on-premises and other SAP cloud solutions. The guided workflow contains automated tasks and instructions for manual tasks to enable an easy and quick integration configuration. 

Cloud Integration Automation service: Benefits  

Following are the benefits of using Cloud Integration Automation service: 

  • Provides planning capabilities to plan integration 
  • Comes with standardized and intuitive user interface 
  • Accelerates cloud adoption by reducing the overall integration time 
  • Integrated parameter management 
  • Traceability of all activities 

Cloud Integration Automation service: Guided workflow 

Upon subscribing to and utilizing the Cloud Integration Automation service for any supported integration scenario, the application generates a guided workflow that includes all the necessary tasks to complete the integration 

Below are some of the highlights of the workflow 

  • Provides integration entity or component information 
  • Fetch the underlying integration landscape  
  • Offers role-based implementation of each task 
  • Provides automated tasks 
  • Provides step by step manual instructions 
  • Provides integration guidance at each component level 

Cloud Integration Automation service: step-by-step 

Step 1: Select the required integration scenario 

Log in to Cloud Integration Automation service home page and select “Plan for integration” 

Select the required scenario from the list for e.g. “Travel Expense Processing with SAP Concur Expense Professional(1M1)” 

Step 2: Generate role-based workflow 

Click on select systems 

Provide system details for each component and click on “Generate Workflow” 

Step 3: Assign the tasks to the right experts 

Go to “My Inbox”, select “I Agree” 

Verify the system information and click on “Confirm Systems” 

Assign the tasks to experts and click on “Confirm Role Assignment” 

Step 4: Run and monitor the tasks until the completion of integration 

Start implementing each task and click on “Task Completed” once the task is completed 

You can monitor the tasks by clicking on “Scenario Monitoring” 

Supported public cloud scenarios 

Currently Cloud Integration Automation service supports around 50+ public cloud scenarios for which you can use to generate workflows. Below is the list of supported scenarios. 

  • Travel Expense Processing with SAP Concur Expense Professional (1M1) 
  • Automatic Market Rates Management (1S4)  
  • Payroll Processing with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll (1NL)  
  • Credit Agency Integration (1RY)  
  • Customer Payments (1S0)  
  • Digital Payments (1S2)  
  • Opportunity-to-Order with SAP Cloud for Customer (1VP)  
  • Restricted Party Screening with SAP Watch List Screening (1WE) 
  • SAP S/4HANA for Enterprise Contract Management (1XV)  
  • Import Connection setup with SAP Analytics Cloud (1YB)  
  • Digital Payments Sales (1Z1) 
  • External Billing (1Z6)  
  • Logistics with Third-Party Warehouse Management (1ZQ)  
  • External Workforce Procurement via SAP Fieldglass (22K)  
  • Integration of Procurement with External Suppliers (2EJ)  
  • Integration of Sales with External Buyers (2EL) 
  • Integration of Payment Advice with Buyers and Suppliers (2MB)  
  • Guided Buying Capability with SAP Ariba Buying (2NV)  
  • Continuous Control Monitoring with SAP Process Control (2OH)  
  • Integration to SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Enterprise Contract Assembly (2OQ)  
  • International Trade Management with SAP GTS  
  • Key Risk Indicator Monitoring with SAP Risk Management (2U2)  
  • Automated Provisioning via SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance (3AB)   
  • Guided Buying for Central Procurement with SAP Ariba Buying (3EN)  
  • Payroll Processing with SAP ERP HCM Payroll (3UP)  
  • Third-Party Shop Floor Execution - Process Industry (3W3)  
  • Third-Party Shop Floor Execution - Discrete Industry (3W4)  
  • Service Order Processing with SAP Field Service Management (49X)  
  • Automation of Source-to-Pay with SAP Business Network (42K)  
  • Automation of Order-to-Invoice with SAP Business Network (4A1)  
  • Workforce Management with SAP Master Data Integration (Inbound)  
  • Setting Up SAP Ariba Buying (4AI)  
  • Contract Management with SAP Ariba Contracts (4AZ)  
  • Contract for Central Procurement with Ariba Contracts (4B0)  
  • Sourcing with SAP Ariba Sourcing (4BL)  
  • SAP Central Invoice Management (4N6)  
  • Central Procurement with SAP Ariba Sourcing (4QN)  
  • Services Procurement with SAP Business Network and SAP Fieldglass (4R2) 
  • Digital Payments Foundation (53V)  
  • ABAP Core Data Services Extraction for SAP Datasphere (53L)  
  • Subscription Management with Sales Billing (57Z)  
  • Subcontracting with SAP Business Network (5I2)   
  • Subscription Management with Convergent Invoicing (5IK)  
  • Automation of Central Procurement Quotes with Ariba Network (5JT)  
  • Real Estate Integration between S/4HANA cloud with C4RE (5VX)  
  • Core HR with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (JB1)  
  • MRP Change Request Integration with SAP Business Network (65D)  
  • Solution Order Quotation Management with SAP CPQ (6BV)  
  • Resource Management capability in SAP Project and Resource Management (6JO)  
  • Integrate SAP S/4HCE with SAP Sales and Service Cloud (6KO)  
  • S/4HANA Cloud for Projects, Collaborative Project Management (6JN)  
  • Integration to Icertis for Contract Assembly (6V2) 
  • 3SL Migration Precheck of S/4 - CIAS Connection   

You can find all the scenarios: What is Cloud Integration Automation Service? | SAP Help Portal 

Conclusion 

Supporting over 50+ public cloud integration scenarios, the Cloud Integration Automation service is a powerful, user-friendly framework that generates guided workflows to expedite cloud adoption journey, enhance integration efficiency and lower overall effort.

Related links:

What is Cloud Integration Automation Service? | SAP Help Portal
