entry.title: Future-Proofing SAP AMS: A Strategic Framework for 2025 & Beyond
entry.content:
Future-Proofing SAP AMS: A Strategic Framework for 2025 & Beyond

Introduction

Over the last several years, I have been involved in multiple SAP AMS transitions following S/4HANA go-lives across different customer environments. While each program had its own complexity, one pattern consistently stood out: once the project teams exited, AMS struggled to keep pace with the new operational reality of S/4HANA and cloud-based landscapes.

In this blog, I am sharing what I have personally observed while leading SAP Basis and AMS delivery teams, why traditional AMS models struggle after S/4HANA go-live, and what has worked in practice to build a more future-ready SAP AMS operating model.

What I Observed When AMS Remained Reactive After S/4HANA Go-Live

In several programs I supported, AMS teams were structured around a traditional incident-driven model. This approach worked reasonably well in ECC environments, but in S/4HANA landscapes it quickly became unsustainable. Incident volumes increased, resolution cycles became longer, and teams spent most of their time reacting instead of stabilizing.

What I learned is that S/4HANA environments demand predictive operations, not reactive support. Teams that introduced proactive monitoring, early alerts, and preventive maintenance were able to reduce disruptions significantly. Where AMS remained reactive, instability persisted even months after go-live.

Why Automation Became Non-Negotiable in the AMS Programs I Managed

In the early phases of AMS onboarding, many operational tasks were still handled manually-user administration, system checks, transport validations, and log reviews. This consumed a large portion of the team’s capacity and left little time for root cause analysis or improvement initiatives.

Across the AMS programs I led, stability improved only after automation was treated as a foundation rather than an enhancement. Introducing automation across L1, L2, and L3 support reduced repetitive effort and improved consistency. More importantly, it allowed teams to shift focus from firefighting to continuous improvement and operational readiness.

Lessons Learned Managing AMS in Hybrid and Cloud Landscapes

As customers moved to hybrid and cloud-based SAP landscapes, AMS complexity increased noticeably. Issues were no longer limited to the SAP application layer but often involved hyperscaler platforms, network dependencies, security controls, and shared responsibility boundaries.

In these environments, AMS teams that lacked cloud operating maturity struggled with escalations and ownership clarity. What worked better was aligning AMS processes with cloud-native operations-integrating SAP Cloud ALM, using hyperscaler monitoring tools, and establishing clear governance for cost, capacity, and security. This alignment reduced friction between teams and improved overall predictability.

Applying SAP Activate Principles Beyond Implementation

While SAP Activate is widely used during implementation, I have seen real benefits when its principles are extended into AMS operations. In several engagements, AMS teams adopted fit-to-standard thinking, sprint-based enhancements, and controlled deployment cycles inspired by Activate.

This helped bring structure and transparency to post–go-live operations. Continuous testing automation, clearer documentation practices, and predictable release cycles made AMS more resilient and easier to manage, especially in fast-changing environments.

Moving Beyond SLA-Driven AMS Metrics

One recurring challenge I observed was the disconnect between AMS performance reports and business perception. AMS teams met SLAs, yet business stakeholders remained dissatisfied due to recurring disruptions during critical cycles.

The programs that performed better shifted focus from SLA-only metrics to business-oriented outcomes. Measuring system stability during month-end, process performance, reduction in disruptions, and user productivity provided a more accurate view of AMS effectiveness. This change also improved conversations with business stakeholders and built greater trust.

Building Resilience Into Everyday AMS Operations

With increasing cyber risks and compliance requirements, resilience became a key focus area in AMS delivery. In practice, this meant embedding disaster recovery readiness, high availability validations, security monitoring, and access reviews into regular operations rather than treating them as separate activities.

In the environments I worked with, automating parts of DR testing and security checks helped teams stay prepared without adding excessive manual effort. This approach significantly improved confidence during audits and critical business periods.

How AMS Roles Are Evolving in Practice

Another important shift I observed is the evolution of AMS skill requirements. Successful AMS teams today are no longer purely technical or functional. They combine SAP Basis knowledge with cloud, automation, security, and strong process understanding.

Teams that invested in cross-skilling especially in automation and observability, were better equipped to manage modern SAP landscapes. This shift also improved team engagement, as engineers moved from repetitive tasks to more value-driven work.

Key Takeaways

  • From my experience, reactive AMS models struggle to support modern S/4HANA landscapes
  • Automation must be treated as a foundation, not an optional improvement
  • Cloud-ready operating models are essential for hybrid and hyperscaler environments
  • Business-aligned metrics provide a more accurate measure of AMS success
  • Future-ready AMS teams require cross-skilled, automation-enabled resources

Conclusion

Based on my experience leading SAP AMS and Basis delivery teams, SAP AMS does not struggle because S/4HANA is unstable. It struggles when operating models fail to evolve with the platform. Organizations that design AMS around predictive operations, automation, cloud readiness, and business outcomes achieve faster stabilisation and stronger business confidence.

My key takeaway is simple: future-proofing SAP AMS is not about adding more processes or tools, but about applying practical experience, accountability, and continuous learning to how support is delivered.

Let’s Discuss

How has your SAP AMS model evolved after S/4HANA go-live? What changes made the biggest difference in improving stability and trust?

I look forward to learning from your experiences.

entry.title: My highlights of the SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release
entry.content:
Welcome to 2026 and welcome to my SAP Cloud ERP 2602 product release highlights! This blog post guides you through the key improvements of the 2602 release of SAP Cloud ERP, focusing on how they support customers in running and evolving their core business processes. And it was again not easy to decide what to declare as highlights amongst the large number of innovations delivered. It's our 34th major release over the years, and I have collected an interesting range across functional, foundational and user experience capabilities. And of course, the AI journey continues to boost both well-known and new ERP processes to a new levels. We're all in on AI.

I wish the team would have granted me more space to talk you through all innovation shipped with the 2602 release , take this blog post as an appetizer for our team’s deep dive blogs per line of business. Prefer video over text? Take a look at my product update video, where my digital twin guides you through the key highlights. 

 

A new operating model for integrated business processes 

With the first release of 2026, we walk the talk of our SAP Business Suite and introduce a range of SAP-managed Integrated Business Processes, removing the complexity of integrating and monitoring multiple cloud solutions from our customer's and partner's activity list. We have carefully listened to your wishes and SAP delivers co-provisioning, functional and technical integration, including lifecycle management, allowing these activities to move in the background while customers focus on their core business. By shifting responsibility for aligned system provisioning, functional and technical integration, and lifecycle management from customers to SAP, we reduce complexity behind the scenes and enables a more seamless suite experience.

* Click here to access the links mentioned in the slide above

As an initial step, release 2602 delivers SAP-managed integration for two critical end-to-end processes as part of an Early Adopter Care (EAC) program. In Workforce Management, SAP provides SAP-managed provisioning and integration between SAP Cloud ERP and SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, supporting a streamlined Recruit-to-Retire process with consistent employee and financial data from day one. For Operational Procurement, integrated processes across SAP Cloud ERP, SAP Ariba Buying, and SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management simplify Procure-to-Pay activities and support a more unified procurement landscape.

These capabilities are enabled by blueprint-based provisioning, which changes how solution instances are deployed, integrated, and managed across the run phase. Instead of manual setup, customers can activate selective solutions or in the future complete suites that are provisioned and come already fully integrated together. Guided by a new suite experience in SAP for Me and based on SAP landscape modeling best practices, SAP applies a desired-state-based reconciliation to ensure transparency, consistency, and long-term stability across the application landscape.

 

AI innovations

SAP Joule for Consultants: Practical enhancements for your everyday project work

With this first release of year 2026, SAP Joule for Consultants continues to mature as a day-to-day companion for project focused workers, offering efficient access to trusted content, better transparency, and smoother workflows – on demand. A new SAP Joule for Consultants console brings ‘What’s New’ release notes, an integrated prompt library, and, where relevant, administrative insights such as usage metrics and system settings into one central entry point, helping teams stay aligned with current innovations.

 

 

Joule now also surfaces SAP Notes and SAP Knowledge Base Articles (KBAs) directly within conversations, based on existing customer entitlements. This allows consultants to reference validated SAP guidance without leaving their context, while administrators retain control through standard s-user assignments. Usability improvements further support efficient work: Quick links simplify navigation across Joule features, the conversation character limit has been increased to 10,000 characters to accommodate larger inputs such as code or detailed scenarios, and public SAP content sources have been refreshed and expanded.

Enhanced citation visibility improves transparency by clearly indicating the origin of information, including public web sources when applicable.

 

Finally, the initial ingestion of SAP Signavio Process Navigator reference content lays the groundwork for more architecture-aware guidance in future releases.

 

Finance

Accounting Accruals Agent (beta)

In the dynamic landscape of financial management, the introduction of the beta version of Accounting Accruals Agent marks a thoughtful stride towards empowering finance professionals with innovative tools tailored for efficiency. This intelligent agent draws from AI-driven capabilities to meticulously craft accrual proposals, transforming the traditionally labor-intensive process into a streamlined operation. By analyzing accounting policy documents, sifting through historical data, and executing precise calculations, this agent reduces the substantial time accountants typically spend during period-end accruals. The newfound simplicity in the ‘Manage Accrual Proposals’ app not only enhances the speed of reviewing and posting proposals but also offers detailed, AI-backed explanations for each calculated entry. This ensures that general ledger accountants gain not just time but also trust in AI’s role in augmenting their decision-making processes, thereby enabling a smoother and more efficient period-end close. This feature is going to be made generally available in SAP Cloud ERP 2602.

 

SAP User Experience

AI-assisted task automation (beta)

In everyday work, many tasks in SAP Cloud ERP follow the same patterns: Reviewing data, triggering follow-up steps, or keeping processes moving. With AI-assisted task automation, SAP introduces smart helpers that support users exactly in these moments. Built with generative AI and embedded directly in My Home, these helpers can take over routine steps within SAP applications while keeping users in control whenever decisions or data changes are required. Instead of replacing human judgement, the focus is on reducing manual effort and helping users progress through their tasks more smoothly. Over time, this creates a more natural way of working with automation, one that adapts to real user needs and daily workflows. Customers interested in shaping this capability early can join the beta program to explore the feature and provide feedback that will influence future AI-driven experiences in SAP Cloud ERP.

Check out this link to sign up for the beta testing and shape the future of AI innovations: https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#campaign/4086 

 

Retail

Assortment module management 

Many non-retail industries integrate retail capabilities into their ERP systems to enhance customer services and collaboration, even in B2B. Most organizations today are expected to react faster to changing customer expectations while keeping operations efficient and scalable. This requires tools that simplify everyday work for planners and merchandisers, reduce operational friction, and make it easier to translate data and insights into action. In this context, intelligent assistance within core retail processes becomes increasingly important, especially where decisions around assortments directly influence customer experience and business outcomes.

In the area of Retail, Joule’s integration into assortment module management supports planners by making common tasks more accessible and less time-consuming. Instead of navigating multiple screens, users can rely on natural language interactions to create, update, or terminate assortments directly within the application. This reduces dependency on deep technical knowledge and helps teams complete routine tasks with greater confidence and efficiency. As a result, merchandising and category managers can spend less time on operational steps and more time focusing on assortment strategy and customer-centric planning.

For more information, please consult SAP Help Portal.

 

Asset Management

Maintenance notification creation and screening with Joule

In Asset Management, keeping maintenance processes running smoothly depends on timely and accurate notifications, often created under time pressure and by users outside of specialized maintenance roles. With Joule integrated into the maintenance notification process in SAP Cloud ERP, creating and screening notifications becomes more straightforward and accessible. Users can describe an issue in natural language and capture key details such as the technical object, priority, and description without navigating complex transaction flows. Moreover, users can access notifications in the ‘Manage Maintenance Notification’ SAP Fiori app (F5777), enabling quick acceptance and conversion into maintenance orders within a single conversational context. As a result, operators spend less time on documentation, while maintenance teams and managers benefit from clearer, more consistent information to plan and execute maintenance activities effectively.

 

SAP Activate innovations

SAP Activate introduces several innovations for the 2602 release, starting with a dedicated activation and implementation guidance for customers adopting SAP-managed integrations in the Early Adopter Care program, mentioned earlier.

Customers implementing SAP Cloud ERP will continue to benefit from easier access to implementation information with Joule, which is embedded in the ’Roadmap Viewer’ application on SAP for Me. Additionally, implementation teams can access up-to-date implementation guidance in nine languages: Chinese, English, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Portuguese, and Spanish. Change your language preferences in SAP for Me to view content in another language.

Customers conducting the upgrade to the 2602 release can leverage the lean upgrade roadmap in the ‘Roadmap Viewer’ app or in SAP Cloud ALM to guide their team through the upgrade and post-upgrade activities. 

 

SAP Cloud ALM updates

In transformation projects, teams often invest a lot of time turning workshop outcomes, documents, and process discussions into structured requirements and test assets. With the latest updates in SAP Cloud ALM, this work becomes more streamlined across the project lifecycle. AI-assisted  requirements generation helps teams create initial requirements automatically based on Fit-to-Standard workshop transcripts, solution processes, and other project documentation, giving project members a solid starting point that can be reviewed and refined instead of built from scratch.

As project scopes evolve, requirements can now be moved easily between projects, supporting reuse and reducing duplication.

 

 Further enhancements focus on governance and test preparation.

New APIs for manual test cases, process hierarchies, and features make it easier to integrate SAP Cloud ALM into existing tool landscapes and automate project reporting or oversight. All SAP Cloud ALM APIs can be found on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

During test preparation, teams can now define where screenshots are required as test evidence, improving transparency and auditability during execution.

 

Updates to release assessment and scope dependency

Smarter upgrades in SAP Cloud ERP require a clear understanding of customer´s individually relevant applications and scope items. The release assessment and scope dependency (RASD) tool continues to evolve, incorporating customer feedback to make impact analysis more transparent and easier to work with. Recent updates simplify how assessment results are shared, allowing users to download content across all tiles, or selected ones, into a single ZIP file with structured Excel outputs that can be reviewed, filtered, and discussed across distributed project teams.

Beyond usability improvements, RASD now provides more precise guidance for upgrade decisions. The introduction of a successor view helps identify recommended follow-on apps, supporting smoother transition planning.

In addition, enhanced views in the personalized 'What’s New Viewer' clearly differentiate between activated, used, and impacted scope items, helping teams focus on what truly matters in their system.

Together, these enhancements support more informed discussions, reduce uncertainty during release preparation, and help teams approach upgrades with greater clarity and confidence.

 

Other innovations across various LoBs

Supply Chain Management – Warehouse management

Interface to warehouse automation systems for efficiently processing warehouse orders

In the evolving landscape of warehouse management, the integration of warehouse automation systems is set to significantly enhance operational efficiency. By seamlessly distributing warehouse orders to automated subsystems, businesses can ensure smooth and coordinated task execution. This interface not only sends out orders but also receives confirmations of warehouse tasks, creating a continuous feedback loop that ensures transparency and efficiency. Such integration significantly cuts down manual intervention, allowing for a more streamlined process that minimizes errors and enhances productivity. The main advantage lies in the ability to process warehouse orders more efficiently, capitalizing on automation to handle tasks that were once labor-intensive. This means warehouse operations can maintain a high level of accuracy while handling greater volumes, ultimately enhancing the overall supply chain performance and reliability.

 

 

Manufacturing

Production order combination enablement

In the Manufacturing line of business, we are happy to introduce production order combination enablement, which offers a practical solution to streamline operations and enhance efficiency. By merging identical operations from different production orders into a single consolidated order, manufacturers can optimize their processes right from the ‘Manage Production Orders’ app. This functionality allows for the creation, maintenance, and confirmation of combined orders, which in turn supports effective cost distribution and settlement through new event-based costing. By reducing setup times and overhead charges, this approach not only increases production throughput but also achieves considerable cost savings. This feature empowers manufacturers to focus their efforts on boosting output while maintaining a keen eye on cost efficiency, creating a more agile and responsive production environment.

 

Professional Services

Intercompany cost allocations reconciliation review booklet

In the Professional Services domain, the enhancement of the ‘Intercompany Review Booklet’ app offers a significant boost in transparency and traceability for intercompany cost allocations. By displaying the complete end-to-end document flow, this app helps reconcile management accounting postings with billing and accounts receivable documents. This comprehensive view is invaluable during closing procedures, as it allows businesses to ensure their data's completeness by clearly identifying services and expenses that have been billed, are partially billed, or remain unbilled. Furthermore, the app provides audit-relevant information on billed intercompany services, offering businesses the assurance and documentation needed for clear internal and external audits. This capability aids organizations in maintaining robust financial processes while enhancing their ability to track and manage intercompany transactions efficiently. Starting with release 2602, the report will include an enhanced breakdown of billed entries, tracing them all the way to the receiver FI journal entry/affiliated expenses.  

 

Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management

Enhanced integration of project plan information with SAP Cloud ERP

In the domain of Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management, enhancing the integration of project plan information with SAP Cloud ERP was one of the items discussed and designed in our customer product councils. This innovation facilitates seamless synchronization of project plan data between SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Project and Resource Management, enabling a more cohesive project management experience. Users can manually trigger updates to project dates in SAP Cloud ERP, ensuring that information remains current and accurate. Furthermore, the automated bi-directional synchronization of project plan data significantly reduces the manual effort involved in data maintenance, allowing teams to focus on strategic initiatives. With greater scope control and improved integration, organizations can enjoy comprehensive visibility of critical information across different solutions, thus enhancing data quality and operational efficiency. This development empowers project managers with the tools needed to effectively monitor and control project progress, fostering better decision-making and resource allocation throughout the project lifecycle.

 

Summary

I hope this overview of the SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release highlights has provided helpful insights into the latest updates and enhancements as well as excitement for the upgrade. As SAP Cloud ERP continues to evolve, these innovations aim to support more efficient processes, clearer guidance, and a smoother experience across implementations and upgrades.

Let me know which innovation stands out most to you and what your personal highlights from this release are: Feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

In the coming weeks, we’ll take a closer look at additional business- and industry-specific innovations in follow-up blogs. Be sure to visit our community page to connect with SAP experts, ask questions, and exchange feedback. To stay up to date with future content, follow the PSCC_Enablement tag and keep an eye out for upcoming posts.

Feel free to follow me at BeSchulze in the community and on LinkedIn to not miss any updates. 

Let’s keep advancing together—towards a smarter, more connected cloud ERP future.

Yours,

Bert

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602: Final What's New & Product Assistance available
entry.content:
With immediate effect, the final What's New information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 is now available.

To access the final What’s New information, please use the What’s New Viewer. In addition, the final Product Assistance (aka Application Help) for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 is available. Please use the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Help Portal page to access it.

For you as a customer, we recommend to also use the Release Assessment and Scope Dependency (RASD) tool. The Release Assessment and Scope Dependency (RASD) tool provides you with a personalized and tailored view on What’s New information based on the activated and used scope within your system. The information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 will be available in RASD within the next few days. A valid Customer S-user ID is required for login. We recommend to use RASD to prepare for upgrades and updates of your system and to focus on the new and changed features that are relevant for you as a customer.

You can use the commenting feature for What’s New. With this feature, authors can evaluate your feedback and incorporate it into the documentation, if needed. We hope that by opening this channel of communication, we can learn how to further improve our What’s New content for you. To use this feature, you need to be logged into the Help Portal. The feature will only be available in the English version of the documents. To learn more about how the feedback process works in SAP Help Portal, see Giving Documentation Feedback.

If you want to get an exclusive preview of upcoming innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 and surrounding solutions, check out the SAP Cloud ERP Early Release Series.

This series will showcase live sessions led by product experts across the SAP Cloud ERP portfolio on a broad range of innovations, including AI-driven features and advancements with Joule, tailored to selected lines of business and industries. Enjoy expert demos, insider previews, and real-time Q&A. Read this blog post to learn more.

All sessions will be accessible via the SAP Learning Hub (access for SAP Customers and Partners. A valid Customer S-user ID is required for login.). You can register for upcoming sessions via the registration page. All recordings of past events will be available here.

entry.title: Enhance security with new CQCs
entry.content:
We are excited to introduce a new/expanded service from SAP Enterprise Support that ensures the security and high availability of your SAP solutions. The Continuous Quality Check "Security Optimization" is designed to thoroughly analyze, verify, and enhance the security of your SAP cloud solution. We have three (3) workstreams available covering SAP S/HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP SuccessFactors and SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP).

After a detailed security analysis, the service will provide recommendations to improve your configuration and authorizations. For this pilot delivery, SAP will assign a dedicated expert to guide you through the process.

Upon completion of the service, you will receive a comprehensive report that includes an executive summary, detailed findings, and recommendations to mitigate risks and enhance your security posture. You can expect to receive the results approximately one week after the session.

If you wish to participate, please ensure you meet the following prerequisites:

  • Grant remote access to your SAP cloud solution to SAP.
  • Be available to collaborate with SAP delivery experts in multiple remote sessions within a mutually agreed 4-6 week timeframe in Q1 2026.
  • Be willing to provide open and honest feedback on the service content and respond to our survey requests.
  • Please note that all workstream activities must be completed by March 15, 2026.

We look forward to working with you and helping you enhance your SAP security.

Contact us today to get started.  
esac@sap.com

Additional information about the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council can be found here.

entry.title: Get Ready for 2602 Upgrade of SAP Cloud ERP Public Edition
entry.content:
Introduction

During this weekend of Jan. 17-18, we can see the T system to be upgraded to 2602 of SAP Cloud ERP Public Edition, and D and P systems in four weeks during February 14-15. This blog intends to do a quick highlight of what has changed since 2408 Upgrade.  The content is limited to CBC Based 3 System Landscape.

 

Highlights of 2602 Upgrade

Shortened Major Upgrade Window (UMW)

From 2408 Upgrade, SAP operations team was able to reduce the UMW from 24 to 8 hours.  This reduction trend keeps going on: from 2508 Upgrade, the UMW has been further reduced to 4 hours.  The 2602 Upgrade will be the same.

In the below Downtime Window picture, the P system upgrade starts from 01:00 UTC on Sunday. That is 20:00 EST on Saturday. By midnight of New York time, the upgrade ends.  Therefore, the customer has an entire Sunday to perform post-upgrade tasks.

Downtime Window for SAP Cloud ERP Public Edition 2602 Upgrade

Below picture have a clear illustration about the upgrade process for the D and T systems.  If you want to learn more about the upgrade process, I have a good explanation in my blog Understand Upgrading and Patching Processes of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Detailed Upgrade Process for the D and T systems

 

What to Test after T System Upgrade

There is a wrong conception that after T system upgrade, the customers will conduct testing on new features and functions. I happen to run into a picture giving a good explanation on this topic.  As illustrated in the below slide, even after upgrade to 2608, T-system still has 2508 content; therefore, no new features or functions are available for testing. Rather, you use this system to test out what is working up to now in the old release content (2508) but in the new system (2602). 

T-System Still Contains 2508 Content after 2602 Upgrade

The 2602 Content becomes available after the D-System is upgraded, and a new transport is created and becomes available to deliver the 2602 Content to the T-System.  See the illustration in below picture.

T-System Content Is Upgraded to 2602 with a Transport from D-System after Its Upgrade

 

Transports Aging Issue

This is not a new topic, but worth highlighting again. For the compatibility concern, transports follow N+1 rule.  This N is related with major upgrades like 2602.  For example, if you created many transports on a 2502 system, they need to be moved to P-System before 2602 upgrade. Otherwise, they are aged to be N+2.  The 2602 T and P systems won’t accept them.  In comparison, any transports created on a 2508 system, i.e., current release, have no problem to be imported into T and P systems after upgrading to 2602 release.

 

Key Dates of 2602 Upgrade

With the 2602 Upgrade going on, we should keep the following key dates in mind:

  • January 14 is the last day to request and provision 2508 T system.
  • From January 14, all new systems requested/provisioned are in 2602 release.  D and P systems will be in the same version.
  • January 17-18 is for T system upgrade
  • January 31 – February 1 is for Starter, Parter TDD and sandbox system upgrade.
  • February 14-15 is for D and P system upgrades.

 

References

  • My Blog: Understand Upgrading and Patching Processes of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • My Blog: FAQ on Upgrading SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 3-System Landscape Upgrade & Maintenance Schedule (December 5, 2025)
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Software Lifecycle Management for Customers (September 3, 2025)

entry.title: AI innovations highlights in SAP Cloud ERP 2602
entry.content:
The release of SAP Cloud ERP 2602 continues SAP’s focus on embedding intelligence directly into business processes, quietly, purposefully, and where it matters most. In this blog, you’ll find a guided look at the key AI innovations introduced with the 2602 release, as highlighted in the product blog post by Bert Schulze. Rather than showcasing AI as a standalone capability, the focus is on how these innovations support customers in running, adapting, and evolving their core business processes across finance, sales, manufacturing, procurement, and beyond.

With the 2602 release, SAP Cloud ERP builds on its existing foundation by supporting everyday work with intelligence that is more contextual, connected, and task focused. At the heart of this evolution is an agentic AI framework, where specialized, task-specific agents take on clearly defined responsibilities based on real business context, data, and rules. These agents work together behind the scenes, while Joule serves as the orchestration layer that brings insights, recommendations, and next steps together in a natural, conversational way. Whether supporting a finance expert with complex classifications or helping teams respond faster to operational issues, intelligence is applied exactly where decisions are made. Take a moment to explore the accompanying video for a closer look at how these AI-driven capabilities quietly support everyday work and point toward a more adaptive way of running enterprise processes.

Take a look at the short video below to see how these AI-driven capabilities quietly support everyday work and are shaping a more adaptive way of running enterprise processes.

 

Agentic AI use case highlights

Finance

International Trade Classification Agent (beta)

When a single misclassified product can delay a shipment or trigger compliance questions, international trade classification quickly becomes a task where precision matters as much as speed. Inthe 2602 release, the International Trade Classification Agent supports product classification specialists in this sensitive part of the process by reasoning over product characteristics and applicable trade regulations. It proposes customs tariff numbers and commodity codes and explains how each recommendation was derived, making review and approval straightforward. This shifts the expert’s role from manual lookup to informed validation, while keeping full transparency and auditability. In practice, teams can expect significantly less effort spent on repetitive classification tasks, up to a 50% reduction, while lowering the risk of non-compliance.

 

Accounting Accruals Agent

Period-end accruals are a familiar pressure point in finance: important, repetitive, and often constrained by tight timelines. The beta version of the Accounting Accruals Agent tackles this challenge by supporting teams with proposing accruals based on accounting policy documents, historical data, and calculated values, helping shift the work from manual preparation to focused review. Accrual proposals are presented directly in the ‘Manage Accrual Proposals’ app, along with clear explanations that show how each figure was derived. This transparency makes it easier for general ledger accountants to validate and post accruals with confidence, without losing control over the process. As a result, teams can reduce the time spent on period-end activities while maintaining consistency and auditability, supporting a smoother close cycle.

For more information, see Accounting Accruals Agent.

 

Embedded AI highlights

Sales

Automatic creation of sales orders from unstructured data (premium) - AnyDOX adoption

Sales teams often receive purchase orders in formats that don’t fit neatly into systems, PDFs attached to emails, scanned documents, or images that still require careful manual entry. With the current release, internal sales representatives can upload these unstructured files and let the system extract the relevant information into a sales order request, proposing values such as the sold-to party based on the document content. What used to be a repetitive transcription task becomes a short review step, allowing sales teams to focus more on customer interactions and less on administrative work. Multilanguage support and the ability to train the extraction logic through SAP Document AI help ensure the process works reliably across regions and document types. The result is a smoother order intake process that reduces manual effort while keeping sales operations responsive and consistent.

Check out this dedicated page on SAP Help Portal to learn more.

 

Finance

Period comparisons and AI insights for product profitability review booklet

Looking at product profitability often starts with a simple question: What changed and why? The latest enhancements to the product profitability review booklet help sales accountants explore this question more systematically by introducing period comparisons for margins and cost of goods sold. Built-in views for margin overview and COGS breakdown are complemented by AI-generated insights that highlight notable developments between periods, offering guidance on where a closer look may be worthwhile. Additional dimensions, functional currency display, and an extensible CDS view support more flexible market segment analysis without losing consistency. Together with the new commenting feature, this creates a clearer, more connected view of product performance that supports informed discussions and decisions.

For more information, discover enhancements in the product profitability review booklet.

 

Manufacturing

AI-assisted production routing proposal and copy routing

Creating a new production routing often starts by searching for something that already exists and adapting it to fit, an approach that works, but takes time and careful attention. The newly introduced innovation, AI-assisted production routing proposal and copy routing, supports production engineers, planners, and master data specialists by identifying similar routings based on material names, descriptions, and bills of material. Instead of rebuilding routings from the ground up, users receive suggestions they can copy and adjust, turning setup work into a focused refinement step. This helps reduce repetitive data entry and lowers the risk of inconsistencies across routings. Over time, teams benefit from faster setup, more consistent master data, and a smoother path from planning to production.

Eager to learn more? Check out our dedicated pages on intelligent scenario to find similar materials for routing proposal and creating a routing using the AI-assisted material search.

 

 

Cross topic: Situation handling

AI-assisted situation handling (beta)

When critical issues surface in day-to-day operations, the real challenge is often not awareness but knowing what to do next. This is where AI-assisted situation handling comes into play, supporting business users by complementing automated alerts with context-aware guidance tailored to their roles and responsibilities. By capturing situation data together with its business context, the system can generate targeted recommendations that help users assess options and act more quickly. Customizable prompts and the ability to incorporate data from SAP, third-party, and external sources ensure that advice reflects real operational conditions. In practice, this leads to faster resolution of situations, cutting response times by up to 70%, and helps teams stay focused on decisions rather than diagnostics.

 

 

Joule innovations highlights

Procurement

Conversational search for local and central purchase requisition status

Tracking the status of a purchase requisition often means switching between apps, systems, and document numbers just to answer a simple question. With the latest updates, conversational search in Joule allows procurement users to ask directly about the status of local or central purchase requisitions and their follow-on documents, without navigating into multiple SAP Fiori apps. Users can reference familiar identifiers, such as requisition numbers, connected-system document IDs, or SAP Ariba cart numbers and receive the relevant status in one place. This shortens the path from question to answer and reduces interruptions in daily work. Over time, procurement teams gain faster visibility into requisition progress and can respond to inquiries with greater confidence and less effort.

 

Conversational search for centrally managed purchase requisition status

Similarly to the innovation described above, conversational search in Joule allows users to check the approval and follow-on document status of centrally managed purchase requisitions without switching between SAP Fiori apps. A simple query is enough to see whether a requisition has progressed to a purchase order, acknowledgment, goods receipt, or invoice receipt. This removes friction from everyday follow-ups and helps teams stay informed without interrupting their workflow. As a result, procurement professionals can respond faster to internal requests and keep processes moving smoothly.

 
Conversational search for central procurement business documents

In central procurement , finding the right document often means knowing exactly where to look and having the time to navigate there. With this release conversational search in Joule allows users to search and filter central procurement business documents simply by asking, whether they are looking for contracts nearing expiration, rejected supplier confirmations, or purchase orders tied to a specific supplier or system. Results are presented together with direct navigation links to the relevant SAP Fiori apps, turning search into a natural entry point rather than a separate task. This makes it easier to move from question to action without breaking focus. Over time, procurement teams gain faster access to the information they need and more confidence in managing centrally governed processes.

 

Don’t miss: The GenAI extensibility assistant

As we roll out the new 2602 features, we also want to highlight a game-changer from the previous cycle that is rapidly becoming a standard for key users. If you haven't yet explored the GenAI-based extensibility assistant, now is the time. This tool allows key users to generate custom fields and logic simply by describing their requirements in natural language. It’s not just about speed; it ensures your logic is consistent and "clean core" compliant by design. To see this assistant in action and learn how to enable it, check out this deep dive on extensibility assistant for key users.

 

Summary 

📽 Register for our SAP Cloud ERP 2602 Early Release Series! 

Between January 12-16, we are hosting a series of 22 expert-led live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release. On our landing page you can register for the entire series or pick the sessions most relevant to you. 

🔎 Find all our assets  

The release 2602 showcases more than 130 innovation highlights across the portfolio. Check out our release document for all the details!

We at Cloud ERP and SCM Product Success offer a service as versatile as our product itself. Check out the numerous offerings our team has created for you below:

entry.title: Converting to the 3-System Landscape – Part 1: What’s in It for You
entry.content:
Co-Author: Dennis Leslie

For quite some time now, the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 3-system landscape has been generally available to our customers. In this landscape, SAP Central Business Configuration is leveraged for implementation, ongoing adaptation and extension of business processes.

This is a significant upgrade from the previous 2-system landscape. For the implementation and ongoing adaptation and extension of business processes, early customers used the so-called Manage Your Solution app. Later adopters were fortunate to use SAP Central Business Configuration from the start.

Now, both 2-system landscape setups can be converted to the advanced 3-system landscape, unlocking numerous benefits, such as:

  • An additional test system for enhanced stability
  • Localization as a self-service for SAP S/4HANA Cloud supporting ~160 countries/regions
  • The parallel line feature for safe testing of data migration and business process extensions
  • Comprehensive extensibility options
  • Additional scope items and configuration settings

Stay tuned for our next blog posts in this blog series and explore the power of the 3-system landscape today! To learn more, check out the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Three-System Landscape page on SAP Community.

Going forward, SAP plans to build more features only available in the 3-system landscape as the capabilities provided by SAP Central Business Configuration and the 3-system landscape are required for these new innovations. To learn more about the advantages and the availability of features that require the 3-system landscape, please see SAP Note 3643616.

If you liked this blog, please leave us a thumbs up at the top. Also, make sure to follow the SAP Central Business Configuration tag or follow this dedicated blog collection to stay up to date with the latest blog posts.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q4-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
Happy New Year and cheers to a sustainable year ahead! As we kick off 2026, I’m back with my quarterly blog series about the latest innovations and highlights in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. In this edition, I’m covering:

  • Multi-Impact Categories
  • Streamlined Energy Management
  • Mass Upload and API Enhancements for GHG Data Collections
  • Emission Factor Management & AI-Mapping Enhancements
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Enablement Updates: Webinar, Learning Journey & Scenario Guide
  • BASF Coatings’ Journey with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
  • Additional Information

 

Multi-Impact Categories

One of the most significant innovations this quarter is the introduction of multi-impact categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, moving the product beyond carbon. Built on the same ERP-driven data foundation, governance model, and auditability, the latest updates extend the calculation engine to cover additional environmental impact categories. This lets you monitor a broader spectrum of environmental pressures without changing the way you integrate data or run calculations.

Think of multi-impact categories as different lenses on how your operations affect the Earth system. Aligned with planetary boundaries, they translate the data you already have into indicators for climate and other dimensions like land use, biosphere integrity, and biogeochemical flows. That means you can see where improvements in one area risk shifting burdens elsewhere – and manage those trade-offs with real numbers.

This matters for reporting because one consistent dataset can now serve multiple frameworks (e.g., CSRD, SBTi FLAG), reducing parallel tools and strengthening credibility with synchronized, audit-ready figures for sustainability, finance, and controlling. But this also matters for decision-making because placing multi‑impact indicators alongside financial and operational KPIs brings sustainability into core business steering. A richer picture of environmental pressure helps identify where reductions also improve efficiency, resilience, and brand value – and where hidden risks accumulate. This supports a shift from compliance‑driven reporting to performance‑driven management, where sustainability becomes a source of competitiveness and innovation.

Importantly, nothing changes in how you run the system. You still reuse ERP data, automate activity data collection, map to imported or pre‑delivered factors, and execute one centralized footprint calculation. The difference is that the same setup now delivers additional impact categories and result views, so your existing data and methods serve a growing list of corporate and product requirements – without extra integrations or parallel logic.

Footprint Results with additional Impact Categories

To learn more about this innovation, its business rationale, and how it supports your reporting requirements, check out my deep dive blog post: Multi-Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. It also includes a step-by-step walkthrough of the overall workflow and the enhanced apps. For complete documentation and technical details, visit SAP Help: Calculating Footprints for Different Impact Categories.

We will also publish additional blog posts in the SAP Community, explaining in detail how you can map the multi-impact calculation results to various reporting requirements. Stay tuned!

 

Streamlined Energy Management

Managing energy data for footprint calculations has often been repetitive and time-consuming. Previously, you had to enter the same energy data and meter readings multiple times for different calculation variants, making workflows cumbersome and prone to errors. This complexity increased further when handling periodic meter readings and energy bills across multiple locations.

With the latest release, we’ve simplified this process significantly: For all newly created footprint calculations, energy bills and meter readings are now managed separately from the footprint inventory using two new types of GHG data forms. This means you can collect periodic energy data via the Record GHG Data app and reuse it across multiple calculations without redundant entries. Data maintenance is now independent of calculation variants, saving time and improving consistency.

We’ve also introduced more flexibility: you can calculate energy-related footprints based on energy sources only, without the need for an energy flow model, which is a major advantage for Corporate Carbon Footprint (CCF) calculations. The user experience has been improved in the Calculate Footprints app as well, with data readings displayed directly on the first page of the inventory for quick access.

In the following, I’ll briefly summarize the required process steps and what has changed in the existing apps. For the full documentation, see Maintain Energy Bills and Meter Readings Using GHG Data Forms on SAP Help.

To use the new approach, start by preparing your footprint inventory scope. In the Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes app, activate form-based data collection for energy bills and meter readings. If you plan to use meter readings in your energy flow model, make sure to include Direct Emissions and Energy Consumptions under Value Chain Steps. For energy bills, this step isn’t required.

Define Footprint Inventory Scope with Form-Based Data Collection

Next, configure your energy sources in the Model Energy Flows app. When creating an energy source, choose Enter Energy Bills if you want to manage consumption through the Energy Bills form, or Use Meter Readings and Planned Consumptions for meter-based data. Meters themselves are created in the Manage Locations app and must be assigned to the relevant plants. If you include meters in your energy flow model, they need to be in place before creating the footprint inventory.

With the scope and energy sources ready, create GHG data collections for the relevant plants and periods in the Manage GHG Data Collections app. Then, record your periodic energy data in the Record GHG Data app. You can enter values directly in the UI. Alternatively, you can download the template for offline editing and mass upload, or you can use the enhanced API for automating data entry and connecting smart meters – see the following chapter for details. Validation checks help ensure consistency, for example by flagging deviations greater than 30% from previous readings.

Record Meter Readings in GHG Data Form

Finally, run your calculation in the Calculate Footprints app. Newly created inventories no longer show separate tabs for energy bills and meter readings – instead, these values are maintained in the GHG data forms, and the Data Readiness section provides an overview of form status and associated models.

Calculate Footprints: Data Readiness

 

Mass Upload and API Enhancements for GHG Data Collections

Managing GHG data across multiple locations and form types can be a challenge, especially when dealing with large datasets. That’s why we’re introducing a powerful new capability, allowing mass upload for GHG data forms. You can now upload different types of forms – such as energy bills, meter readings, business activities, and waste data – across locations using a single template in the Record GHG Data and Manage GHG Data Collections apps. The template includes tabs for each form type, making it easy to consolidate and manage data efficiently without repetitive manual entry. For all details, check SAP Help: Working with GHG Data Collections and Record GHG Data.

To take automation even further, the GHG Data Forms API has been enhanced with new endpoints and parameters for mass updates. This means you can retrieve and update forms programmatically, integrate with external systems, and even connect smart meters or IoT devices directly. Check out the API on SAP Business Accelerator Hub: GHG Data Forms.

These improvements reduce manual effort, increase accuracy, and save time. They’re also addressing several of the most requested features on SAP Influence.

 

Emission Factor Management & AI-Mapping Enhancements

High‑quality emission factors are the backbone of accurate and audit‑ready footprint results. The broader and better your factor library, the fewer workarounds you need, the faster you can onboard, and the more confidently you can answer customer and regulatory requests. Last quarter, we’ve expanded the default datasets, improved import templates and governance, and refined AI‑assisted mapping – so you can source, structure, and apply factors with less manual effort and higher precision.

With this release, the Manage Emission Factors app expands its default dataset substantially. We’ve added two new source packages and refreshed an existing one to broaden coverage and improve alignment with logistics and fuel methodologies. Newly added are:

  • GLEC Framework (Smart Freight Centre): Harmonized logistics factors across road, rail, air, ocean/inland waterways, and parcel/last‑mile; coverage for fuels and energy (TTW/WTT), logistics sites and equipment (warehousing, refrigeration, handling), plus rules for distance, allocation, and data quality aligned with ISO 14083.
  • German Environment Agency (Umweltbundesamt, UBA): Factors for fossil fuels including natural gas, hard coal, lignite, heating oils, diesel, gasoline, LPG, and more.

In addition, the UK DEFRA packages have been updated and now include the full set of emission factors. For more information, see Using Default Emission Factor Data on SAP Help.

To make onboarding and governance smoother, and to align with the latest features, we’ve updated the import templates in the Manage Emission Factors app. The simple template (v3) and the LCA template (v5) now support impact categories beyond Climate Change, including the selection of an LCIA method and its characterization factor per dataset – so you can manage multi‑impact content consistently. In the Dataset Sources tab, you can add a source URL to the dataset for traceability, and unit validation has been tightened via the Dimensions column. We also streamlined context fields by adding a drop-down list to the Boundary column and moving it to the Emission Dataset tab to keep dataset‑level semantics in one place. For all changes, visit SAP Help: Emission Factors Data.

With the Custom Datasets feature in the Manage Emission Factor app, you can assemble component datasets into a single, composite dataset to derive an overall emission factor when a product or activity’s direct factor is unknown – leveraging known emissions of its parts to enable accurate footprint calculations. Now, those custom datasets also support multi-impact categories, so you can use it also for emission factors beyond climate change. For more information, see Creating Custom Datasets and Emission Factors on SAP Help.

Custom Dataset with Multi-Impact Emission Factors

We’ve also refined the AI-assisted emission factor mapping in the Manage Purchased Product Footprints app. This powerful feature suggests mappings between products (or product groups) from your ERP system and emission factors from LCA databases. A new option, Show Enhanced Footprint Suggestions, is enabled by default and shifts similarity scores to prioritize commodity code first, then text similarity, then country/region. This enhances mapping precision where commodity codes are available. If your ERP master data or LCA packages lack commodity codes, you can switch the option off to revert to text‑matching. Exact matches are elevated when product names and dataset names align and commodity codes are consistent (or both absent), even if descriptions are missing. To reduce false negatives, AI no longer pre‑filters by unit convertibility and you’ll only be blocked at release if unit conversions are missing in product master data. And for categories with sparse activity‑based data, AI now includes spend‑based factors when they rank among the top 10 suggestions. For all details, check SAP Help: Using AI to Map Emission Factors to Purchased Products and Product Groups.

Refined AI-assisted Emission Factor Mapping with Enhanced Footprint Suggestions

 

Other Release Highlights

To help you better understand your transport network at a glance, we added map visualizations for locations and transport routes across key apps. In the Manage Locations app, you can view locations on an interactive map along with details such as address, geocoordinates, postal code, and country or region. The Manage Transport Activities app now also provides a map-based view of generated routes and legs, helping you visualize transport flows more intuitively. On top of that, the Manage Transport Activities and Calculate Transport Footprints apps include an enhanced quick view for locations with an embedded map display. This means you can access location details and see them on a map instantly, streamlining your workflow and saving time.

Visualization of Transport Route and Legs

In my previous blog post, I introduced the Source Input Items feature in the Manage Footprint Results app that gives granular visibility into the inputs driving product emissions to identify hotspots and guide targeted decarbonization actions. We now enhanced this feature with the ability to generate source input items for cyclical calculations. This makes footprint analysis more comprehensive, especially for products calculated based on cyclical processes. On SAP Help, you find more information about source input items: Viewing the Footprint Results, and examples on cycle calculations: Calculating Cycles.

Another update improves data handling and coverage in the Import Business Transactions app: You can now add business transaction data to supplement imported records, with clear tracking of imported and added entries. New columns – Imported Records, Added Records, and Entry Method – provide transparency on how data enters the system, ensuring complete coverage for footprint calculations. The consolidated data (imported and added records) is then used to calculate footprints. For details, see Import Business Transactions, and for more information about business transactions' behavior, see Business Transactions Types on SAP Help.

Finally, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management is now available in two additional regions: Europe (Frankfurt) and Brazil (São Paulo), both on AWS. This expansion supports customers operating in these regions with improved availability and compliance.

 

Enablement Updates: Webinar, Learning Journey & Scenario Guide

To make it easier for you to adopt the latest capabilities, we’ve expanded our enablement portfolio with new content and updates across multiple channels. Together with BearingPoint, we hosted a webinar that gives an overall introduction of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and also takes a closer look at multi-impact categories and what they mean for your sustainability strategy. Supported by a system demo, the session explains how these new dimensions help you move beyond carbon to a more holistic view of environmental performance. If you missed it, you can watch the full recording here:

We’ve also updated the Learning Journey Establishing Corporate Carbon Footprint Emissions with Advanced Configurations. A new unit now explains how to calculate GHG Scope 3.4 emissions using the ERP-centric transport footprint calculation capabilities introduced last year. This addition is particularly valuable for organizations looking to leverage existing ERP data for transport-related emissions without building parallel processes. It’s a practical guide to help you understand how these capabilities fit into your overall footprint model and reporting requirements.

In addition, we also published a new Scenario Guide that includes detailed process steps for calculating Scope 3.4 emissions based on data already available in your ERP systems: Process 8 – Calculating Scope 3.4 Emissions Using Business Transaction Data.

These enablement updates are designed to make adoption easier and faster, so you can focus on turning sustainability data into actionable insights. Whether you prefer learning through webinars, structured journeys, or detailed guides, we’ve got you covered.

 

BASF Coatings’ Journey with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

Recently, I joined the Inside SAP S/4HANA Cloud Podcast to discuss sustainability and share real-world examples of how our solutions create impact. A highlight was my conversation with Maximilian Bauer from BASF Coatings, who explained how they use SAP Sustainability Footprint Management to tackle the complexity of sustainability in their business.

BASF Coatings operates in a highly dynamic environment, producing thousands of product variations with every color shade counting as a new product. This creates massive data challenges when calculating footprints. With SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, BASF Coatings can now:

  • Scale and automate carbon footprint calculations for hundreds of thousands of products.
  • Integrate seamlessly into existing systems, embedding sustainability into daily operations.
  • Gain actionable insights to offer more sustainable products and make data-driven decisions.

As Maximilian Bauer said: “You can only improve what you can measure – and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management offers us exactly this.”

Looking ahead, BASF Coatings is moving beyond carbon to multi-impact footprints, covering categories like abiotic resource depletion to ensure responsible use of finite resources. They’re also scaling innovations such as biomass balance and ChemCycling®, replacing fossil-based raw materials with renewable or recycled alternatives. These steps position BASF to meet growing global demand for sustainable products and stay ahead of regulatory expectations.

BASF Coatings’ journey illustrates why we’re evolving SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: from carbon-only to multi-impact sustainability footprints, enabling companies to manage risk, cost, and growth across multiple environmental dimensions – all embedded in core business processes.

In the podcast, I also shared our broader vision: embedding sustainability into business processes, leveraging a single trusted data foundation, and using AI to make sustainability intelligent and scalable. By expanding beyond carbon toward multiple impact categories, we help businesses move from compliance to competitive advantage.

Listen to the full episode on Apple Podcast or Spotify.

 

Additional Information

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions that have been released, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.

For exploring and experimenting in a live system, register for the free SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Trial. You’ll receive an e-mail with access information within seconds after your registration and can then test the solution at your own convenience within a 30-day trial period. It also includes a wide range of guided tours designed to help you navigate through all the features and functions comprehensively. Recently, we also added new tours and will shortly release additional ones, representing the latest features and an enhanced user experience.

To stay up to date on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I’ll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product’s new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I’m also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.
